title: Tim Sherwood jokes at Hugo Lloris' expense after Tottenham keeper's injury at Brighton & Hove Albion
text:
Former Tottenham manager Tim Sherwood shocked viewers by cruelly joking about Hugo Lloris' excruciating arm injury while the Spurs goalkeeper was being cared for in hospital in the aftermath of their defeat at Brighton.

Lloris suffered an agonising accident two minutes into the 3-0 defeat at the Amex Stadium, falling awkwardly backwards over his line and dislocating his left elbow in an incident that left him prone on the turf for several minutes.

The visiting captain screamed in pain as he was eased onto a stretcher and taken for emergency treatment in shocking scenes following Brighton's early opening goal.

Sherwood managed Lloris during his brief spell in charge of Spurs during the 2013/14 season

Sherwood met Pochettino as Tottenham boss when Spurs' current coach was at Southampton

Lloris's injury compounded a dismal day for Spurs and united both sets of fans in sympathy for the World Cup-winning France skipper.

In a bizarre piece of post-match punditry, analyst Sherwood, who was working for the Premier League channel alongside former England striker Michael Owen, appeared to make fun of Lloris's plight.

Speaking about the preceding mistake from the man he managed during a brief spell in charge of Spurs in the 2013/14 season, Sherwood offered a tasteless remark about Lloris's arm.

'Listen, Hugo would hold his arms up if he could hold both up and say, "that's a mistake,"', said Sherwood, drawing an uneasy smile from host Manish Bhasin.

Lloris 🙏🏼 — David de Gea (@D_DeGea) October 5, 2019

Fellow top players, including Manchester United goalkeeper David de Gea, publicly expressed their support for Lloris.

'The news is not good from the hospital,' Tottenham coach Mauricio Pochettino told reporters, admitting that the freak injury had 'emotionally impacted' his side's performance.

'Everyone saw, on the pitch, when he landed it was not a good situation.'

Captain Lloris landed on his arm while trying to stop Brighton's first goal in the early stages

Understudy Paulo Gazzaniga replaced Lloris but was unable to prevent striker Aaron Connolly adding goals in either half for Brighton as the Seagulls cruised to their first home win of the season.

The result extended Spurs' winless away run to 10 matches, leaving them in a lowly 11th in the Premier League at the end of a week that started with a record home defeat for an English team in European competition.

Lloris conceded seven times as Bayern Munich stormed to a 7-2 win in the Champions League at the Tottenham Hotspur Stadium, including five goals in a second-half capitulation from Pochettino's floundering side.
description: Lloris suffered an agonising accident two minutes into the 3-0 defeat at the Amex Stadium, drawing a bizarre remark from Sherwood that seemed to be at his former keeper's expense.
